text: my name is Jill I'm a New York Times
recipe texture stylist and recipe writer
and I do all my cooking right here in my
New York City apartment in my tiny
little kitchen in this week's New York
Times Magazine Nick larb writes about
the first time in his life when he had a

Greece with his girlfriend at the time a
teenager and he ordered a Roquefort
salad so in honor of Nick's
life-changing salad we're gonna make a
salad that I came up with and I hope
changes your life I doubt it but maybe
the important thing about making a salad
is to wash the greens properly if you
don't fully dry them the vinaigrette
will not stick to the lettuce leaves and
you can do that either in a salad
spinner or you can just shake it dry and
then lay it out on a towel
once these are dry the way I would pack
them to store them in the refrigerator
is just get one of these Ziploc bags
then you take a paper towel
once you have dampened it squeeze out
the water and just lay that in the bag
over the greens and then seal it up and
put in the fridge one thing about a tiny
kitchen is you have to clean up as you
go
kind of a pain but once you start doing
dishes you get really good at it and
then we can do the next thing which is
